Lebesgue Integration of Complex Value Function

Posted on 2022-11-13 Edited on 2022-11-19

Let (Ω,F,μ)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mu)(Ω,F,μ) be a measure space.Let f:Ω→Cf: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{C}f:Ω→C be a complex valued function.
It can be written as f(ω)≐g(ω)+ih(ω)f(\omega) \doteq g(\omega) + i h(\omega)f(ω)≐g(ω)+ih(ω), where g,hg, hg,h are both real functions on Ω\OmegaΩ.

Definition [Measurability]. A function fff is measurable F\mathcal{F}F if both ggg and hhh are.

Definition [Integral]. fff is integrable if both ggg and hhh are, and its integral is defined by

∫f dμ≐∫g dμ+i∫h dμ. \int f \, d \mu \doteq \int g \, d \mu + i \int h \, d \mu. ∫fdμ≐∫gdμ+i∫hdμ.

Theorem. fff is integrable if and only if ∣f∣|f|∣f∣ is integrable.

Remark: the integral of the former is complex-valued, while the later is real-valued.

Proof.
The claim follows from that

max⁡{∣g∣,∣h∣}≤∣f∣=∣g∣2+∣h∣2≤∣g∣+∣h∣. \max \{ |g|, |h| \} \le |f| = \sqrt{|g|^2 + |h|^2} \le |g| + |h|. max{∣g∣,∣h∣}≤∣f∣=∣g∣2+∣h∣2​≤∣g∣+∣h∣.

□\square□

Theorem [Linearity]. Let f1,f2f_1, f_2f1​,f2​ be integrable.
Then f1+f2f_1 + f_2f1​+f2​ is integrable, and

∫f1+f2 dμ=∫f1 dμ+∫f2 dμ. \int f_1 + f_2 \, d \mu = \int f_1 \, d \mu + \int f_2 \, d \mu. ∫f1​+f2​dμ=∫f1​dμ+∫f2​dμ.

Proof.
The integrability of f1+f2f_1 + f_2f1​+f2​ follows from the one of ∣f1+f2∣|f_1 + f_2|∣f1​+f2​∣, which is integrable as ∣f1+f2∣≤∣f1∣+∣f2∣|f_1 + f_2| \le |f_1| + |f_2|∣f1​+f2​∣≤∣f1​∣+∣f2​∣.

To prove linearity, let f1=g1+ih1f_1 = g_1 + i h_1f1​=g1​+ih1​ and f2=g2+ih2f_2 = g_2 + i h_2f2​=g2​+ih2​.
Then

∫f1+f2 dμ≐∫g1+g2 dμ+i∫h1+h2 dμ=∫g1 dμ+i∫h1 dμ+∫g2 dμ+i∫h2 dμ≐∫f1 dμ+∫f2 dμ. \begin{aligned} \int f_1 + f_2 \, d \mu &\doteq \int g_1 + g_2 \, d \mu + i \int h_1 + h_2 \, d \mu \\ &= \int g_1 \, d \mu + i \int h_1 \, d \mu + \int g_2 \, d \mu + i \int h_2 \, d \mu \\ &\doteq \int f_1 \, d \mu + \int f_2 \, d \mu. \end{aligned} ∫f1​+f2​dμ​≐∫g1​+g2​dμ+i∫h1​+h2​dμ=∫g1​dμ+i∫h1​dμ+∫g2​dμ+i∫h2​dμ≐∫f1​dμ+∫f2​dμ.​

□\square□

Theorem. If fff is integrable, then

∣∫f dμ∣≤∫∣f∣ dμ. \left| \int f \, d \mu \right| \le \int |f| \, d \mu. ∣∣∣∣∣​∫fdμ∣∣∣∣∣​≤∫∣f∣dμ.

Proof. Let f=g+ihf = g + i hf=g+ih.
Consider first that ggg and hhh are simple functions.
W.L.O.G., assume g=∑k∈[n]xkIAkg = \sum_{k \in [n]} x_k \mathbb{I}_{A_k}g=∑k∈[n]​xk​IAk​​, h=∑k∈[n]ykIAkh = \sum_{k \in [n]} y_k \mathbb{I}_{A_k}h=∑k∈[n]​yk​IAk​​, where Ak∈F,k∈[n]A_k \in \mathcal{F}, k \in [n]Ak​∈F,k∈[n] constitute a partition of Ω\OmegaΩ.

∣∫f dμ∣=∣∫g dμ+i∫h dμ∣=∣∑k∈[n]xk⋅μ(Ak)+i∑k∈[n]yk⋅μ(Ak)∣=∣∑k∈[n](xk+iyk)⋅μ(Ak)∣≤∑k∈[n]∣(xk+iyk)⋅μ(Ak)∣=∑k∈[n]∣(xk+iyk)∣⋅μ(Ak)=∫∣f∣ dμ. \begin{aligned} \left| \int f \, d \mu \right| &= \left|\int g \, d \mu + i \int h \, d \mu \right| \\ &= \left| \sum_{k \in [n]} x_k \cdot \mu (A_k) + i \sum_{k \in [n]} y_k \cdot \mu (A_k) \right| \\ &= \left| \sum_{k \in [n]} \big( x_k + i y_k \big) \cdot \mu (A_k) \right| \\ &\le \sum_{k \in [n]} \left| \big( x_k + i y_k \big) \cdot \mu (A_k) \right| \\ &= \sum_{k \in [n]} \left| \big( x_k + i y_k \big) \right| \cdot \mu (A_k) \\ &= \int |f| \, d \mu. \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​∫fdμ∣∣∣∣∣​​=∣∣∣∣∣​∫gdμ+i∫hdμ∣∣∣∣∣​=∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​k∈[n]∑​xk​⋅μ(Ak​)+ik∈[n]∑​yk​⋅μ(Ak​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​=∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​k∈[n]∑​(xk​+iyk​)⋅μ(Ak​)∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​≤k∈[n]∑​∣∣∣​(xk​+iyk​)⋅μ(Ak​)∣∣∣​=k∈[n]∑​∣∣∣​(xk​+iyk​)∣∣∣​⋅μ(Ak​)=∫∣f∣dμ.​

For general integrable f=g+ihf = g + i hf=g+ih, there exists simple functions gn,hng_n, h_ngn​,hn​ such that

  1. lim⁡ngn=g\lim_n g_n = glimn​gn​=g and lim⁡nhn=h\lim_n h_n = hlimn​hn​=h;

  2. ∣gn∣≤∣g∣|g_n| \le |g|∣gn​∣≤∣g∣ and ∣hn∣≤∣h∣|h_n| \le |h|∣hn​∣≤∣h∣ for all n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+;

  3. lim⁡n∫gn dμ=∫g dμ\lim_n \int g_n \, d \mu = \int g \, d \mulimn​∫gn​dμ=∫gdμ and lim⁡n∫hn dμ=∫h dμ\lim_n \int h_n \, d \mu = \int h \, d \mulimn​∫hn​dμ=∫hdμ.

It follows that ∣gn+ihn∣↑∣f∣|g_n + i h_n| \uparrow |f|∣gn​+ihn​∣↑∣f∣.
Hence,

∣∫f dμ∣=∣∫g dμ+i∫h dμ∣=∣lim⁡n∫(gn+ihn) dμ∣=lim⁡n∣∫gn+ihn dμ∣≤(a)lim⁡n∫∣gn+ihn∣ dμ=(b)∫∣f∣ dμ, \begin{aligned} \left| \int f \, d \mu \right| &= \left|\int g \, d \mu + i \int h \, d \mu \right| \\ &= \left| \lim_n \int \left( g_n + i h_n \right)\, d \mu \right| \\ &= \lim_n \left| \int g_n + i h_n \, d \mu \right| \\ &\stackrel{(a)}{\le} \lim_n \int \left| g_n + i h_n \right| \, d \mu \\ &\stackrel{(b)}{=} \int |f| \, d \mu, \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​∫fdμ∣∣∣∣∣​​=∣∣∣∣∣​∫gdμ+i∫hdμ∣∣∣∣∣​=∣∣∣∣∣​nlim​∫(gn​+ihn​)dμ∣∣∣∣∣​=nlim​∣∣∣∣∣​∫gn​+ihn​dμ∣∣∣∣∣​≤(a)​nlim​∫∣gn​+ihn​∣dμ=(b)∫∣f∣dμ,​

where Inequality (a)(a)(a) follows from previous claim, and Inequality (b)(b)(b) follows from monotone convergence theorem.

□\square□

Theorem. Suppose that fn=gn+ihnf_n = g_n + i h_nfn​=gn​+ihn​ are complex integrable functions satisfying ∑n≥1∫∣fn∣ dμ<∞\sum_{n \ge 1} \int |f_n| \, d \mu < \infty∑n≥1​∫∣fn​∣dμ<∞.
Then ∑n≥1fn\sum_{n \ge 1} f_n∑n≥1​fn​ is integrable, and

∫∑n≥1fn dμ=∑n≥1∫fn dμ. \int \sum_{n \ge 1} f_n \, d \mu = \sum_{n \ge 1} \int f_n \, d \mu. ∫n≥1∑​fn​dμ=n≥1∑​∫fn​dμ.

Proof.
By monotone convergence theorem, we have

∫∑n≥1∣fn∣ dμ=∑n≥1∫∣fn∣ dμ<∞. \int \sum_{n \ge 1} |f_n| \, d \mu = \sum_{n \ge 1} \int |f_n| \, d \mu < \infty. ∫n≥1∑​∣fn​∣dμ=n≥1∑​∫∣fn​∣dμ<∞.

Since

∣∑n≥1gn∣≤∑n≥1∣gn∣≤∑n≥1∣fn∣, \Bigg| \sum_{n \ge 1} g_n \Bigg| \le \sum_{n \ge 1} |g_n| \le \sum_{n \ge 1} |f_n|, ∣∣∣∣∣∣​n≥1∑​gn​∣∣∣∣∣∣​≤n≥1∑​∣gn​∣≤n≥1∑​∣fn​∣,

∑n≥1gn\sum_{n \ge 1} g_n∑n≥1​gn​ is integrable.
Via dominated convergence theorem,

∫∑n≥1gn dμ=∑n≥1∫gn dμ. \int \sum_{n \ge 1} g_n \, d \mu = \sum_{n \ge 1} \int g_n \, d \mu. ∫n≥1∑​gn​dμ=n≥1∑​∫gn​dμ.

Similar argument shows that ∑n≥1hn\sum_{n \ge 1} h_n∑n≥1​hn​ is integrable, and

∫∑n≥1hn dμ=∑n≥1∫hn dμ. \int \sum_{n \ge 1} h_n \, d \mu = \sum_{n \ge 1} \int h_n \, d \mu. ∫n≥1∑​hn​dμ=n≥1∑​∫hn​dμ.

Therefore, ∑n≥1fn\sum_{n \ge 1} f_n∑n≥1​fn​ is integrable, and

∫∑n≥1fn dμ≐∫∑n≥1gn dμ+i∫∑n≥1hn dμ=∑n≥1∫gn dμ+∑n≥1i∫hn dμ≐∑n≥1∫fn dμ. \begin{aligned} \int \sum_{n \ge 1} f_n \, d \mu &\doteq \int \sum_{n \ge 1} g_n \, d \mu + i \int \sum_{n \ge 1} h_n \, d \mu \\ &= \sum_{n \ge 1} \int g_n \, d \mu + \sum_{n \ge 1} i \int h_n \, d \mu \\ &\doteq \sum_{n \ge 1} \int f_n \, d \mu. \end{aligned} ∫n≥1∑​fn​dμ​≐∫n≥1∑​gn​dμ+i∫n≥1∑​hn​dμ=n≥1∑​∫gn​dμ+n≥1∑​i∫hn​dμ≐n≥1∑​∫fn​dμ.​

□\square□

Reference

[1] P. Billingsley, Probability and measure Anniversary Edition, 3rd ed. New York: Wiley, 1995.

Khintchine Inequality

Posted on 2022-11-08 Edited on 2022-12-08

Definition (ppp-norm). Given p∈N+p \in \mathbb{N}^+p∈N+ and a random variable X∈LpX \in L_pX∈Lp​, define

∥X∥p≐(E[∣X∣p])1/p. \Vert X \Vert_p \doteq \Big( \mathbb{E} \big[ |X|^p \big] \Big)^{1 / p}. ∥X∥p​≐(E[∣X∣p])1/p.

We verify that this is a norm.
Denote a=∥X∥pa = \Vert X \Vert_pa=∥X∥p​, b=∥Y∥pb = \Vert Y \Vert_pb=∥Y∥p​ and s=a+bs = a + bs=a+b.
Via the convexity of ∣⋅∣p| \cdot |^p∣⋅∣p,

∥as⋅Xa+bs⋅Yb∥pp=E[∣as⋅Xa+bs⋅Yb∣p]≤E[as⋅∣Xa∣p+bs⋅∣Yb∣p]=as+bs=1. \begin{aligned} \left\Vert \frac{a}{s} \cdot \frac{X}{a} + \frac{b}{s} \cdot \frac{Y}{b} \right\Vert_p^p &= \mathbb{E} \Bigg[ \left\vert \frac{a}{s} \cdot \frac{X}{a} + \frac{b}{s} \cdot \frac{Y}{b} \right\vert^p \Bigg] \\ &\le \mathbb{E} \Bigg[ \frac{a}{s} \cdot \left\vert \frac{X}{a} \right\vert^p + \frac{b}{s} \cdot \left\vert \frac{Y}{b} \right\vert^p \Bigg] \\ &= \frac{a}{s} + \frac{b}{s} \\ &= 1. \end{aligned} ∥∥∥∥∥​sa​⋅aX​+sb​⋅bY​∥∥∥∥∥​pp​​=E[∣∣∣∣∣​sa​⋅aX​+sb​⋅bY​∣∣∣∣∣​p]≤E[sa​⋅∣∣∣∣∣​aX​∣∣∣∣∣​p+sb​⋅∣∣∣∣∣​bY​∣∣∣∣∣​p]=sa​+sb​=1.​

Further, for q,p∈N+,q≤pq, p \in \mathbb{N}^+, q \le pq,p∈N+,q≤p, we have ∥X∥q≤∥X∥p\Vert X \Vert_q \le \Vert X \Vert_p∥X∥q​≤∥X∥p​, since via the convexity of ∣⋅∣p/q| \cdot |^{p / q}∣⋅∣p/q,

∥X∥qp=(E[∣X∣q])p/q≤E[(∣X∣q)p/q]=∥X∥pp. \Vert X \Vert_q^p = \Big( \mathbb{E} \big[ |X|^q \big] \Big)^{p / q} \le \mathbb{E} \Big[ \big( |X|^q \big)^{p / q} \Big] = \Vert X \Vert_p^p. ∥X∥qp​=(E[∣X∣q])p/q≤E[(∣X∣q)p/q]=∥X∥pp​.

Khintchine Inequality. Given p∈N+p \in \mathbb{N}^+p∈N+, a⃗=(a1,…,an)∈Rn\vec{a} = (a_1, \ldots, a_n) \in \mathbb{R}^na=(a1​,…,an​)∈Rn and independent Rademacher random variable X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​,

∥∑i∈[n]ai⋅Xi∥p≤p+1p⋅p⋅∥a⃗∥2∈O(p⋅∥a⃗∥2). \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot X_i \right\Vert_p \le \frac{\sqrt{p + 1}}{\sqrt{p}} \cdot \sqrt{p} \cdot \Vert \vec{a} \Vert_2 \in O( \sqrt{p} \cdot \Vert \vec{a} \Vert_2 ). ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ai​⋅Xi​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤p​p+1​​⋅p​⋅∥a∥2​∈O(p​⋅∥a∥2​).

Proof. Suppose that this holds when ppp is even.
Then for odd ppp, by monotonicity of random variable norms,

∥∑i∈[n]ai⋅Xi∥p≤∥∑i∈[n]ai⋅Xi∥p+1∈O(p+1⋅∥a⃗∥2)=O(p⋅∥a⃗∥2). \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot X_i \right\Vert_p \le \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot X_i \right\Vert_{p + 1} \in O \left( \sqrt{p + 1} \cdot \Vert \vec{a} \Vert_2 \right) = O \left( \sqrt{p} \cdot \Vert \vec{a} \Vert_2 \right). ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ai​⋅Xi​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ai​⋅Xi​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p+1​∈O(p+1​⋅∥a∥2​)=O(p​⋅∥a∥2​).

It is left to consider that ppp is even.
Let Z1,…,ZnZ_1, \ldots, Z_nZ1​,…,Zn​ be independent standard normal random variable.
We compare ∥∑i∈[n]ai⋅Xi∥p\left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot X_i \right\Vert_p∥∥∥∥​∑i∈[n]​ai​⋅Xi​∥∥∥∥​p​ with ∥∑i∈[n]ai⋅Zi∥p\left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot Z_i \right\Vert_p∥∥∥∥​∑i∈[n]​ai​⋅Zi​∥∥∥∥​p​.
Observe that both

\begin{align*} \mathbb{E} \Bigg[ \Bigg| \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot X_i \Bigg|^p \Bigg] = \mathbb{E} \Bigg[ \Bigg( \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot X_i \Bigg)^p \Bigg], \\ \mathbb{E} \Bigg[ \Bigg| \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot Z_i \Bigg|^p \Bigg] = \mathbb{E} \Bigg[ \Bigg( \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot Z_i \Bigg)^p \Bigg], \end{align*}

can be expanded into a sum of expectation of monomials.

Each monomial with odd exponents has expectation 000.
Meanwhile, for non-negative even integers m1,…,mnm_1, \ldots, m_nm1​,…,mn​ that sum up to ppp, we have

∏i∈[n](ai)miE[(Xi)mi]=∏i∈[n](ai)mi≤∏i∈[n](ai)miE[(Zi)mi], \prod_{i \in [n]} (a_i)^{m_i} \mathbb{E}[ \left( X_i \right)^{m_i} ] = \prod_{i \in [n]} (a_i)^{m_i} \le \prod_{i \in [n]} (a_i)^{m_i} \mathbb{E}[ \left( Z_i \right)^{m_i} ], i∈[n]∏​(ai​)mi​E[(Xi​)mi​]=i∈[n]∏​(ai​)mi​≤i∈[n]∏​(ai​)mi​E[(Zi​)mi​],

where the last inequality holds since (ai)mi(a_i)^{m_i}(ai​)mi​ and E[(Zi)mi]=(mi−1)!!≥1\mathbb{E}[ \left( Z_i \right)^{m_i} ] = (m_i - 1)!! \ge 1E[(Zi​)mi​]=(mi​−1)!!≥1.

Therefore ∥∑i∈[n]ai⋅Xi∥pp\left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot X_i \right\Vert_p^p∥∥∥∥​∑i∈[n]​ai​⋅Xi​∥∥∥∥​pp​ is dominated term-by-term by ∥∑i∈[n]ai⋅Zi∥pp\left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot Z_i \right\Vert_p^p∥∥∥∥​∑i∈[n]​ai​⋅Zi​∥∥∥∥​pp​.
But ∑i∈[n]ai⋅Zi\sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot Z_i∑i∈[n]​ai​⋅Zi​ follows the distribution N(0,∥a⃗∥2)N(0, \Vert \vec{a} \Vert_2)N(0,∥a∥2​).
Therefore,

∥∑i∈[n]ai⋅Xi∥p≤∥∑i∈[n]ai⋅Zi∥p=∥a⃗∥2⋅((p−1)!!)1/p \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot X_i \right\Vert_p \le \left\Vert \sum_{i \in [n]} a_i \cdot Z_i \right\Vert_p = \Vert \vec{a} \Vert_2 \cdot \big( \left( p - 1\right)!! \big)^{1 / p} ∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ai​⋅Xi​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​≤∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​i∈[n]∑​ai​⋅Zi​∥∥∥∥∥∥∥​p​=∥a∥2​⋅((p−1)!!)1/p

Finally, note that
(p−1)!!≤pp/2⟹((p−1)!!)1/p≤p(p - 1) !! \le p^{p / 2} \Longrightarrow \big( \left( p - 1\right)!! \big)^{1 / p} \le \sqrt{p}(p−1)!!≤pp/2⟹((p−1)!!)1/p≤p​.

□\square□

Remark. See Wikipedia for obtaining a tighter estimation for odd ppp.

Facts.
Suppose that Z∼N(0,1)Z \sim N(0, 1)Z∼N(0,1).
Then

∥Z∥pp≐12π∫−∞∞∣z∣pexp⁡(−12z2) dz=22π∫0∞zpexp⁡(−12z2) dz=22π∫0∞(2u)pexp⁡(−u)⋅12u du,u=z22=2p/2π∫0∞u(p+1)/2−1exp⁡(−u) du=2p/2π⋅Γ(p+12). \begin{aligned} \Vert Z \Vert_p^p &\doteq \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{-\infty}^\infty |z|^p \exp \left( - \frac{1}{2} z^2 \right) \, d z \\ &= \frac{2}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{0}^\infty z^p \exp \left( - \frac{1}{2} z^2 \right) \, d z \\ &= \frac{2}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{0}^\infty (\sqrt{2u})^p \exp \left( - u \right) \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2u}} \, d u, && u = \frac{z^2}{2} \\ &= \frac{ 2^{p / 2} }{ \sqrt{\pi} } \int_{0}^\infty u^{(p + 1) / 2 - 1} \exp \left( - u \right) \, d u \\ &= \frac{ 2^{p / 2} }{ \sqrt{\pi} } \cdot \Gamma \left( \frac{p + 1}{2} \right). \end{aligned} ∥Z∥pp​​≐2π​1​∫−∞∞​∣z∣pexp(−21​z2)dz=2π​2​∫0∞​zpexp(−21​z2)dz=2π​2​∫0∞​(2u​)pexp(−u)⋅2u​1​du,=π​2p/2​∫0∞​u(p+1)/2−1exp(−u)du=π​2p/2​⋅Γ(2p+1​).​​u=2z2​​

Note that, when ppp is odd,

Γ(p+12)=(p−12)!, \Gamma \left( \frac{p + 1}{2} \right) = \left( \frac{p - 1}{2} \right)!, Γ(2p+1​)=(2p−1​)!,

and when ppp is even,

Γ(p+12)=p−12⋯12⋅Γ(12)=p−12⋯12⋅π. \Gamma \left( \frac{p + 1}{2} \right) = \frac{p - 1}{2} \cdots \frac{1}{2} \cdot \Gamma \left( \frac{1}{2} \right) = \frac{p - 1}{2} \cdots \frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\pi}. Γ(2p+1​)=2p−1​⋯21​⋅Γ(21​)=2p−1​⋯21​⋅π​.

Therefore,

2p/2π⋅Γ(p+12)={2π(p−1)!! if  p  is odd , (p−1)!! if  p  is even. \frac{ 2^{p / 2} }{ \sqrt{\pi} } \cdot \Gamma \left( \frac{p + 1}{2} \right) = \begin{cases} \begin{aligned} &\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}} (p - 1)!! &\text{ if }\, p \,\text{ is odd },\, \\ & (p - 1)!! &\text{ if }\, p \,\text{ is even}. \end{aligned} \end{cases} π​2p/2​⋅Γ(2p+1​)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​​π2​​(p−1)!!(p−1)!!​ if p is odd , if p is even.​​

Reference

[1]. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khintchine_inequality

[2]. https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~minilek/madalgo2015/notes1.pdf

Independence

Posted on 2022-08-20 Edited on 2022-09-18

Let (Ω,F,Pr⁡)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \Pr)(Ω,F,Pr) be a probability space.

Independence Events

Definition. A finite collection of events A1,…,An∈FA_1, \ldots, A_n \in \mathcal{F}A1​,…,An​∈F are independent, if for each collection of events B1,…,BnB_1, \ldots, B_nB1​,…,Bn​, for which either Bi=ΩB_i = \OmegaBi​=Ω or Bi=AiB_i = A_iBi​=Ai​, i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], it holds that

Pr⁡[B1∩…∩Bn]=Pr⁡[B1]⋯Pr⁡[Bn]. \Pr[ B_1 \cap \ldots \cap B_n ] = \Pr[ B_{1} ] \cdots \Pr[ B_{n} ]. Pr[B1​∩…∩Bn​]=Pr[B1​]⋯Pr[Bn​].

Since every Bi=ΩB_i = \OmegaBi​=Ω can be suppressed on each side of the equation, this is equivalent to that for each set of distinct indices i1,i2…,iki_1 ,i_2 \ldots ,i_ki1​,i2​…,ik​ between 111 to nnn,

Pr⁡[Ai1∩…∩Aik]=Pr⁡[Ai1]⋯Pr⁡[Aik]. \Pr[ A_{i_1} \cap \ldots \cap A_{i_k} ] = \Pr[ A_{i_1} ] \cdots \Pr[ A_{i_k} ]. Pr[Ai1​​∩…∩Aik​​]=Pr[Ai1​​]⋯Pr[Aik​​].

Definition. An infinite (perhaps uncountable) collection of events {Aθ,θ∈Θ}\{ A_\theta, \theta \in \Theta \}{Aθ​,θ∈Θ} are independent if each of its finite sub-collections of events are independent.

Independence Classes

Definition. A finite classes A1,…,An⊆F\mathcal{A}_1, \ldots, \mathcal{A}_n \subseteq \mathcal{F}A1​,…,An​⊆F are independent, if for each choice of Ai∈Ai,i∈[n]A_i \in \mathcal{A}_i, i \in [n]Ai​∈Ai​,i∈[n], the events Ai,i∈[n]A_i, i \in [n]Ai​,i∈[n] are independent.

Definition. An infinite (perhaps uncountable) collection of classes {Aθ:θ∈Θ}\{ \mathcal{A}_\theta : \theta \in \Theta \}{Aθ​:θ∈Θ} are independent if for each choice of Aθ∈Aθ,θ∈ΘA_\theta \in \mathcal{A}_\theta, \theta \in \ThetaAθ​∈Aθ​,θ∈Θ, the events {Aθ,θ∈Θ}\{ A_\theta, \theta \in \Theta \}{Aθ​,θ∈Θ} are independent.

Observe that by the definition of independence of infinite collection of event, the independence of {Aθ:θ∈Θ}\{ \mathcal{A}_\theta : \theta \in \Theta \}{Aθ​:θ∈Θ} is equivalent to the independence of each finite sub-collection Aθ1,…,Aθk\mathcal{A}_{\theta_1}, \ldots, \mathcal{A}_{\theta_k}Aθ1​​,…,Aθk​​ of the class.

Independent σ\sigmaσ-fields

The following theorem underpins a number of theorems related to independence of random variables.
It states that to decide a collection of σ\sigmaσ-fields are independent, it suffices to show that a collection of π\piπ-systems generating them are independent.

Theorem. If the classes A1,…,An⊆F\mathcal{A}_1, \ldots, \mathcal{A}_n \subseteq \mathcal{F}A1​,…,An​⊆F are independent and π\piπ systems, then σ(A1),…,σ(An)\sigma(\mathcal{A}_1), \ldots, \sigma(\mathcal{A}_n)σ(A1​),…,σ(An​) are independent.

Proof.
Fix A2∈A2,…,An∈AnA_2 \in \mathcal{A}_2, \ldots, A_n \in \mathcal{A}_nA2​∈A2​,…,An​∈An​.

Define

L≐{E∈F:E,A2,…,An are independent.}. \mathcal{L} \doteq \{ E \in \mathcal{F}: E, A_2, \ldots, A_n \text{ are independent.} \}. L≐{E∈F:E,A2​,…,An​ are independent.}.

Lemma. L\mathcal{L}L is a λ\lambdaλ system.

Since L\mathcal{L}L contains the π\piπ system A1\mathcal{A}_1A1​, by π\piπ-λ\lambdaλ theorem, it follows that σ(A1)⊆L\sigma(\mathcal{A}_1) \subseteq \mathcal{L}σ(A1​)⊆L.
Therefore, σ(A1),…,An\sigma(\mathcal{A}_1), \ldots, \mathcal{A}_nσ(A1​),…,An​ are independent.

Repeating the process proves that σ(A1),σ(A2),…,An\sigma(\mathcal{A}_1), \sigma(\mathcal{A}_2), \ldots, \mathcal{A}_nσ(A1​),σ(A2​),…,An​ are independent, and so on.

Proof of the Lemma.

  1. Ω∈L\Omega \in \mathcal{L}Ω∈L.

  2. If E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F, then Eˉ∈F\bar E \in \mathcal{F}Eˉ∈F: if

    Pr⁡[E∩B2∩…∩Bk]=Pr⁡[E]⋅Pr⁡[B2]⋯Pr⁡[Bn]. \Pr[ E \cap B_{2} \cap \ldots \cap B_{k} ] = \Pr[E] \cdot \Pr[ B_2 ] \cdots \Pr[ B_n ]. Pr[E∩B2​∩…∩Bk​]=Pr[E]⋅Pr[B2​]⋯Pr[Bn​].

    where Bi=AiB_i = A_iBi​=Ai​ or Bi=ΩB_i = \OmegaBi​=Ω, i∈[2. . n]i \in [2 .\,.\, n]i∈[2..n], then

    Pr⁡[Eˉ∩B2∩…∩Bn]=Pr⁡[B2∩…∩Bn]−Pr⁡[E∩B2∩…∩Bn]=(1−Pr⁡[E])⋅Pr⁡[B2]⋯Pr⁡[Bn]=Pr⁡[Eˉ]⋅Pr⁡[B2]⋯Pr⁡[Bn] \begin{aligned} \Pr[ \bar E \cap B_2 \cap \ldots \cap B_n ] &= \Pr[ B_2 \cap \ldots \cap B_n ] - \Pr[ E \cap B_2 \cap \ldots \cap B_n ] \\ &= (1 - \Pr[E]) \cdot \Pr[ B_2 ] \cdots \Pr[ B_n ] \\ &= \Pr[\bar E] \cdot \Pr[ B_2 ] \cdots \Pr[ B_n ] \end{aligned} Pr[Eˉ∩B2​∩…∩Bn​]​=Pr[B2​∩…∩Bn​]−Pr[E∩B2​∩…∩Bn​]=(1−Pr[E])⋅Pr[B2​]⋯Pr[Bn​]=Pr[Eˉ]⋅Pr[B2​]⋯Pr[Bn​]​

  3. If Ek∈F,k∈N+E_k \in \mathcal{F}, k \in \mathbb{N}^+Ek​∈F,k∈N+ are pairwise disjoint, and E=∪k≥1EkE = \cup_{k \ge 1} E_kE=∪k≥1​Ek​, then E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F:

    Pr⁡[E∩B2∩…∩Bn]=∑k Pr⁡[Ek∩B2∩…∩Bn]=∑k Pr⁡[Ek]⋅Pr⁡[B2]⋯Pr⁡[Bn]=Pr⁡[E]⋅Pr⁡[B2]⋯Pr⁡[Bn]. \begin{aligned} \Pr[ E \cap B_2 \cap \ldots \cap B_n ] &= \sum_k \, \Pr[ E_k \cap B_2 \cap \ldots \cap B_n ] \\ &= \sum_k \, \Pr[E_k] \cdot \Pr[ B_2 ] \cdots \Pr[ B_n ] \\ &= \Pr[E] \cdot \Pr[ B_2 ] \cdots \Pr[ B_n ]. \end{aligned} Pr[E∩B2​∩…∩Bn​]​=k∑​Pr[Ek​∩B2​∩…∩Bn​]=k∑​Pr[Ek​]⋅Pr[B2​]⋯Pr[Bn​]=Pr[E]⋅Pr[B2​]⋯Pr[Bn​].​

□\square□

Simple Random Variable

Definition. A random variable X:Ω→RX : \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}X:Ω→R is simple, if it has finite range (assumes finitely many values), and for each x∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R,

{ω∈Ω:X(ω)=x}∈F. \{ \omega \in \Omega : X(\omega) = x \} \in \mathcal{F}. {ω∈Ω:X(ω)=x}∈F.

In probability theory, ω\omegaω is often omitted, and {X=x}\{X = x \}{X=x} is short for {ω∈Ω:X(ω)=x}\{ \omega \in \Omega : X(\omega) = x \}{ω∈Ω:X(ω)=x}.
It it easy to see that a random variable can be represented by

X=∑i∈[n]xiIAi, X = \sum_{i \in [n]} x_i \mathbb{I}_{A_i}, X=i∈[n]∑​xi​IAi​​,

where the Ai∈F,i∈[n]A_i \in \mathcal{F}, i \in [n]Ai​∈F,i∈[n] is a finite partition of Ω\OmegaΩ.

Definition. For a finite or countably infinite sequence X1,X2,…X_1, X_2, \ldotsX1​,X2​,… of random variables, σ(X1,X2,…)\sigma(X_1, X_2, \ldots)σ(X1​,X2​,…) is the intersection of all σ\sigmaσ-fields with respect to which each XiX_iXi​ is measurable.

Independence

Definition. A finite or countably infinite sequence X1,X2,…X_1, X_2, \ldotsX1​,X2​,… of simple random variables are independent, if σ(X1),σ(X2),…\sigma(X_1), \sigma(X_2), \ldotsσ(X1​),σ(X2​),… are independent.

We study a several importance properties.

Property 1

Theorem. A finite sequence X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ of simple random variables are independent, if and only if for each x1,…,xn∈Rx_1, \ldots, x_n \in \mathbb{R}x1​,…,xn​∈R,

Pr⁡[X1=x1,…,Xn=xn]=Pr⁡[X1=x1]⋯Pr⁡[Xn=xn]. \Pr[ X_1 = x_1, \ldots, X_n = x_n ] = \Pr[ X_1 = x_1 ] \cdots \Pr[ X_n = x_n ]. Pr[X1​=x1​,…,Xn​=xn​]=Pr[X1​=x1​]⋯Pr[Xn​=xn​].

Proof.
If X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ of random variables are independent, the equation clearly holds.
It suffices to prove the other direction.

For each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], let Xi(Ω)X_i(\Omega)Xi​(Ω) be the range of XiX_iXi​, which is finite.
Define the class

Ai≐{Xi−1(x),x∈Xi(Ω)}∪∅, \mathcal{A}_i \doteq \{ X_i^{-1} (x), x \in X_i(\Omega) \} \cup \emptyset, Ai​≐{Xi−1​(x),x∈Xi​(Ω)}∪∅,

which is a π\piπ-system, since the Xi−1(x),x∈Xi(Ω)X_i^{-1} (x), x \in X_i(\Omega)Xi−1​(x),x∈Xi​(Ω) are pairwise disjoint.
Then A1,…,An\mathcal{A}_1, \ldots, \mathcal{A}_nA1​,…,An​ are independent.
It follows that σ(X1),σ(X2),…\sigma(X_1), \sigma(X_2), \ldotsσ(X1​),σ(X2​),… are independent.

□\square□

Property 2

Next, we prove an important result.
Consider a finite sequence of simple random variables:

X1,1,…Xk1X2,1,…Xk2………Xn,1,…Xkn. \begin{matrix} X_{1, 1}, &\ldots &X_{k_1}\\ X_{2, 1}, &\ldots &X_{k_2}\\ \ldots &\ldots &\ldots \\ X_{n, 1}, &\ldots &X_{k_n}. \end{matrix} X1,1​,X2,1​,…Xn,1​,​…………​Xk1​​Xk2​​…Xkn​​.​

For each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], fi:Rki→Rf_i: \mathbb{R}^{k_i} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}fi​:Rki​→R is a function.
Then

Claim. The fi(Xi,1,…Xki)f_i(X_{i, 1}, \ldots X_{k_i})fi​(Xi,1​,…Xki​​) are independent.

The following theorem states that functions of finite simple random variables are again simple random variables.

Theorem. For a finite sequence X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ of simple random variables,

  1. The σ\sigmaσ-field σ(X1,…,Xn)\sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n)σ(X1​,…,Xn​) consists of the sets

    {ω∈Ω:(X1(ω),…,Xn(ω))∈H}, \{ \omega \in \Omega : \left( X_1(\omega), \ldots, X_n(\omega) \right) \in H \}, {ω∈Ω:(X1​(ω),…,Xn​(ω))∈H},

    where H∈RnH \in \mathcal{R}^nH∈Rn; HHH in this representation can be taken finite.

  2. A simple random variable YYY is measurable σ(X1,…,Xn)\sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n)σ(X1​,…,Xn​) if and only if

    Y=f(X1,…,Xn), Y = f(X_1, \ldots, X_n), Y=f(X1​,…,Xn​),

    for some f:Rn→Rf: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:Rn→R.

Proof of Claim One.
Define the function X:Ω→Rn\pmb{X}: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^nXX:Ω→Rn by

X(ω)≐(X1(ω),…,Xn(ω)). \pmb{X} (\omega) \doteq \left( X_1(\omega), \ldots, X_n(\omega) \right). XX(ω)≐(X1​(ω),…,Xn​(ω)).

For each H∈RnH \in \mathcal{R}^nH∈Rn, define X−1(H)≐{ω∈Ω:X(ω)∈H}\pmb{X}^{-1} (H) \doteq \{ \omega \in \Omega : \pmb{X} (\omega) \in H \}XX−1(H)≐{ω∈Ω:XX(ω)∈H}, and define
and the class of sets

X−1(Rn)≐{X−1(H):H∈Rn}. \pmb{X}^{-1} (\mathcal{R}^n) \doteq \left\{ \pmb{X}^{-1} (H) : H \in \mathcal{R}^n \right\}. XX−1(Rn)≐{XX−1(H):H∈Rn}.

Step One: X−1(Rn)⊆σ(X1,…,Xn)\pmb{X}^{-1} (\mathcal{R}^n) \subseteq \sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n)XX−1(Rn)⊆σ(X1​,…,Xn​).

Observe that for each x=(x1,…,xn)∈Rn\pmb{x} = (x_1, \ldots, x_n) \in \mathbb{R}^nxx=(x1​,…,xn​)∈Rn,

X−1(x)={ω∈Ω:X(ω)=x}=∩i∈[n]{ω∈Ω:Xi(ω)=xi}. \begin{aligned} \pmb{X}^{-1} (\pmb{x}) &= \{ \omega \in \Omega : \pmb{X} (\omega) = \pmb{x} \} \\ &= \cap_{i \in [n]} \{ \omega \in \Omega : X_i(\omega) = x_i \}. \end{aligned} XX−1(xx)​={ω∈Ω:XX(ω)=xx}=∩i∈[n]​{ω∈Ω:Xi​(ω)=xi​}.​

Since {ω∈Ω:Xi(ω)=xi}∈σ(X1,…,Xn)\{ \omega \in \Omega : X_i(\omega) = x_i \} \in \sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n){ω∈Ω:Xi​(ω)=xi​}∈σ(X1​,…,Xn​) for each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], we have

∩i∈[n]{ω∈Ω:Xi(ω)=xi}∈σ(X1,…,Xn). \cap_{i \in [n]} \{ \omega \in \Omega : X_i(\omega) = x_i \} \in \sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n). ∩i∈[n]​{ω∈Ω:Xi​(ω)=xi​}∈σ(X1​,…,Xn​).

Since X\pmb{X}XX, as a function, has finite range, each set
X−1(H) \pmb{X}^{-1} (H) XX−1(H)
is a finite union of sets of the form {ω∈Ω:X(ω)=x}\{ \omega \in \Omega : \pmb{X} (\omega) = \pmb{x} \}{ω∈Ω:XX(ω)=xx}, and therefore belongs to σ(X1,…,Xn)\sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n)σ(X1​,…,Xn​).

Step One: σ(X1,…,Xn)⊆X−1(Rn)\sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n) \subseteq \pmb{X}^{-1} (\mathcal{R}^n)σ(X1​,…,Xn​)⊆XX−1(Rn).

It suffices to prove that X−1(Rn)\pmb{X}^{-1} (\mathcal{R}^n)XX−1(Rn) a σ\sigmaσ-field.
At a high level, this follows from that Rn\mathcal{R}^nRn is a σ\sigmaσ-field.

  1. Since if H∈RnH \in \mathcal{R}^nH∈Rn, then Hˉ∈Rn\bar H \in \mathcal{R}^nHˉ∈Rn, it holds that

    X−1(H)‾=X−1(Hˉ)∈X−1(Rn). \overline{\pmb{X}^{-1} (H)} = \pmb{X}^{-1} (\bar H) \in \pmb{X}^{-1} (\mathcal{R}^n). XX−1(H)​=XX−1(Hˉ)∈XX−1(Rn).

  2. Since if Hk∈Rn,k∈N+H_k \in \mathcal{R}^n, k \in \mathbb{N}^+Hk​∈Rn,k∈N+, then ∪k≥1Hk∈Rn\cup_{k \ge 1} H_k \in \mathcal{R}^n∪k≥1​Hk​∈Rn, it holds that

    ∪k≥1X−1(Hk)=X−1(∪k≥1Hk)∈X−1(Rn). \cup_{k \ge 1} \pmb{X}^{-1} (H_k) = \pmb{X}^{-1} (\cup_{k \ge 1} H_k) \in \pmb{X}^{-1} (\mathcal{R}^n). ∪k≥1​XX−1(Hk​)=XX−1(∪k≥1​Hk​)∈XX−1(Rn).

□\square□

Proof of Claim Two.
Suppose that

Y=f(X1,…,Xn)=f∘X Y = f(X_1, \ldots, X_n) = f \circ \pmb{X} Y=f(X1​,…,Xn​)=f∘XX

for some f:Rn→Rf: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:Rn→R.
Since X\pmb{X}XX has finite range, so does YYY.
For each possible output y∈Ry \in \mathbb{R}y∈R, Y−1(y)Y^{-1} (y)Y−1(y) is a finite union of X−1(x)\pmb{X}^{-1}(\pmb{x})XX−1(xx) over those x\pmb xxx for which f(x)=yf(\pmb{x}) = yf(xx)=y.
It follows that YYY is measurable σ(X1,…,Xn)\sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n)σ(X1​,…,Xn​).

To prove the other direction, suppose that YYY is measurable σ(X1,…,Xn)\sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n)σ(X1​,…,Xn​).
Since it is a simple random variable, it assumes finite values y1,…,yky_1, \ldots, y_ky1​,…,yk​.

  • The σ(X1,…,Xn)\sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n)σ(X1​,…,Xn​)-sets Y−1(yi),i∈[k]Y^{-1} (y_i), i \in [k]Y−1(yi​),i∈[k] forms a partition of Ω\OmegaΩ.

  • Since Y−1(yi)∈σ(X1,…,Xn)Y^{-1} (y_i) \in \sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n)Y−1(yi​)∈σ(X1​,…,Xn​), via previous claim, there exists for each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], a set Hi∈RnH_i \in \mathcal{R}^nHi​∈Rn, such that X−1(Hi)=Y−1(yi)\pmb{X}^{-1}(H_i) = Y^{-1} (y_i)XX−1(Hi​)=Y−1(yi​) and HiH_iHi​ can be taken finite.

  • For each HiH_iHi​, we construct a subset Hi′⊆HiH_i' \subseteq H_iHi′​⊆Hi​, by removing from HiH_iHi​ the x\pmb{x}xx for which X−1(x)=∅\pmb{X}^{-1} (\pmb{x}) = \emptysetXX−1(xx)=∅.
    The Hi′,i∈[n]H_i', i \in [n]Hi′​,i∈[n] are pairwise disjoint.

  • Finally, for each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n] and each x∈Hi′\pmb{x} \in H_i'xx∈Hi′​, define f(x)=yif(\pmb{x}) = y_if(xx)=yi​.
    For all other x∉∪i∈[n]Hi′\pmb{x} \notin \cup_{i \in [n]} H_i'xx∈/∪i∈[n]​Hi′​, define f(x)=0f(\pmb{x}) = 0f(xx)=0.

□\square□

We finish the proof of the claim with another result.

Theorem. Let

X1,1,X1,2,…X2,1,X2,2,………… \begin{matrix} X_{1, 1}, &X_{1, 2}, &\ldots \\ X_{2, 1}, &X_{2, 2}, &\ldots \\ \ldots &\ldots &\ldots \end{matrix} X1,1​,X2,1​,…​X1,2​,X2,2​,…​………​

be a (possibly countably infinite) sequence of independent simple random variables.
For each n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+, suppose the random variable YnY_nYn​ is measurable Fn≐σ(Xn,1,Xn,2,…)\mathcal{F}_n \doteq \sigma(X_{n, 1}, X_{n, 2}, \ldots )Fn​≐σ(Xn,1​,Xn,2​,…).
Then Y1,Y2,…Y_1, Y_2, \ldotsY1​,Y2​,… are independent.

Proof.
For each n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+, define the class

An≐{Xn,i1−1(xi1)∩…∩Xn,ik−1(xik):1≤i1<i2<…<ikxi1,…,xik∈R}, \mathcal{A}_n \doteq \left\{ X_{n, i_1}^{-1} (x_{i_1}) \cap \ldots \cap X_{n, i_k}^{-1} (x_{i_k}) : \begin{matrix} 1 \le i_1 < i_2 < \ldots < i_k \\ x_{i_1}, \ldots, x_{i_k} \in \mathbb{R} \end{matrix} \right\}, An​≐{Xn,i1​−1​(xi1​​)∩…∩Xn,ik​−1​(xik​​):1≤i1​<i2​<…<ik​xi1​​,…,xik​​∈R​},

which is the finite intersections of the sets Xn,k−1(x),k∈N+,x∈RX_{n, k}^{-1} (x), k \in \mathbb{N}^+, x \in \mathbb{R}Xn,k−1​(x),k∈N+,x∈R.
It is easy to see that ∅∈An\emptyset \in \mathcal{A}_n∅∈An​, and An\mathcal{A}_nAn​ is a π\piπ-system.
Further,

  • An\mathcal{A}_nAn​ generates Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​, i.e., σ(An)=Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) = \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)=Fn​:

    • σ(An)⊆Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) \subseteq \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)⊆Fn​: via definition of Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​, Xn,k−1(x)∈FnX_{n, k}^{-1} (x) \in \mathcal{F}_nXn,k−1​(x)∈Fn​, for each k∈N+,x∈Rk \in \mathbb{N}^+, x \in \mathbb{R}k∈N+,x∈R.
      Hence, each element in An\mathcal{A}_nAn​ belongs to Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​, and σ(An)⊆Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) \subseteq \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)⊆Fn​.

    • σ(An)⊇Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) \supseteq \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)⊇Fn​: via definition of An\mathcal{A}_nAn​, Xn,k−1(x)∈AnX_{n, k}^{-1} (x) \in \mathcal{A}_nXn,k−1​(x)∈An​, for each k∈N+,x∈Rk \in \mathbb{N}^+, x \in \mathbb{R}k∈N+,x∈R.
      Hence, each Xn,kX_{n, k}Xn,k​ is measurable σ(An)\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n)σ(An​).
      Via definition of Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​, σ(An)⊇Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) \supseteq \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)⊇Fn​.

  • The An\mathcal{A}_nAn​ are independent: let n1,…,nmn_1, \ldots, n_mn1​,…,nm​ be a finite sequence of indexes in N+\mathbb{N}^+N+.
    Suppose that for each j∈[m]j \in [m]j∈[m],

    Bnj≐Xnj,i1(j)−1(xi1(j))∩…∩Xnj,ik(j)−1(xik(j)). B_{n_j} \doteq X_{n_j, i_1(j)}^{-1} (x_{i_1(j)}) \cap \ldots \cap X_{n_j, i_k(j)}^{-1} (x_{i_{k}(j)}). Bnj​​≐Xnj​,i1​(j)−1​(xi1​(j)​)∩…∩Xnj​,ik​(j)−1​(xik​(j)​).

    Then

    Pr⁡[Bn1∩…∩Bnm]=Pr⁡[∩j∈[m](Xnj,i1(j)−1(xi1(j))∩…∩Xnj,ik(j)−1(xik(j)))]=∏j∈[m]Pr⁡[Xnj,i1(j)=xi1(j)]⋯Pr⁡[Xnj,ik(j)=xik(j)]=∏j∈[m]Pr⁡[Bnj]. \begin{aligned} \Pr[ B_{n_1} \cap \ldots \cap B_{n_m} ] &= \Pr\left[ \cap_{j \in [m]} \left( X_{n_j, i_1(j)}^{-1} (x_{i_1(j)}) \cap \ldots \cap X_{n_j, i_k(j)}^{-1} (x_{i_{k}(j)}) \right) \right] \\ &= \prod_{j \in [m]} \Pr[ X_{n_j, i_1(j)} = x_{i_1(j)}] \cdots \Pr[X_{n_j, i_k(j)} = x_{i_{k}(j)} ] \\ &= \prod_{j \in [m]} \Pr[B_{n_j}]. \end{aligned} Pr[Bn1​​∩…∩Bnm​​]​=Pr[∩j∈[m]​(Xnj​,i1​(j)−1​(xi1​(j)​)∩…∩Xnj​,ik​(j)−1​(xik​(j)​))]=j∈[m]∏​Pr[Xnj​,i1​(j)​=xi1​(j)​]⋯Pr[Xnj​,ik​(j)​=xik​(j)​]=j∈[m]∏​Pr[Bnj​​].​

It follows that the Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​ are independent.

□\square□

Remark. The second claim would be much easier to prove, if fff is measurable Rn/R\mathcal{R}^n / \mathcal{R}Rn/R.

Random Variables and Vectors

Definition. A function X:Ω→RX : \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}X:Ω→R is a random variable, if it is measurable F/R\mathcal{F} / \mathcal{R}F/R (or measurable F\mathcal{F}F for short), i.e.,

[X∈H]=X−1(H)∈F,∀H∈R. [X \in H] = X^{-1}(H) \in \mathcal{F}, \forall H \in \mathcal{R}. [X∈H]=X−1(H)∈F,∀H∈R.

Definition. A function X:Ω→RkX : \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^kX:Ω→Rk is a random vector, if it is measurable F/Rk\mathcal{F} / \mathcal{R}^kF/Rk (or measurable F\mathcal{F}F for short), i.e.,

[X∈H]=X−1(H)∈F,∀H∈Rk. [X \in H] = X^{-1}(H) \in \mathcal{F}, \forall H \in \mathcal{R}^k. [X∈H]=X−1(H)∈F,∀H∈Rk.

Consider a function X:Ω→RkX : \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^kX:Ω→Rk.
For each ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω, we write the iii-th coordinate of X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) as Xi(ω)X_i(\omega)Xi​(ω).
Hence, X(ω)=(X1(ω),…,Xk(ω))X(\omega) = (X_1(\omega), \ldots, X_k(\omega))X(ω)=(X1​(ω),…,Xk​(ω)), and each XiX_iXi​ is itself a function from Ω\OmegaΩ to R\mathbb{R}R.

Theorem. XXX is measurable F/Rk\mathcal{F} / \mathcal{R}^kF/Rk (a random vector), if and only if each XiX_iXi​ is measurable F/R\mathcal{F} / \mathcal{R}F/R ( a random variable).

The proof relies on the following lemma.

Lemma.
L≐{H∈Rk:[X∈H]∈F}⊆Rk\mathcal{L} \doteq \{ H \in \mathcal{R}^k : [X \in H] \in \mathcal{F} \} \subseteq \mathcal{R}^kL≐{H∈Rk:[X∈H]∈F}⊆Rk is a σ\sigmaσ-field.

Proof of the Lemma. Observe that L\mathcal{L}L is closed under complement and countable union:

X−1(Hˉ)=Ω−X−1(H)∈F, and  X−1(∪n≥1Hn)=∪n≥1X−1(Hn)∈F. X^{-1}(\bar H) = \Omega - X^{-1}(H) \in \mathcal{F}, \text{ and }\, X^{-1}( \cup_{n \ge 1} H_n ) = \cup_{n \ge 1} X^{-1}(H_n) \in \mathcal{F}. X−1(Hˉ)=Ω−X−1(H)∈F, and X−1(∪n≥1​Hn​)=∪n≥1​X−1(Hn​)∈F.

□\square□

Proof of the Theorem.

Define

S≐{(−∞,x1]×⋯×(−∞,xk]:x1,…,xk∈R}. \mathcal{S} \doteq \{ (-\infty, x_1] \times \dotsm \times (-\infty, x_k] : x_1, \dots, x_k \in \mathbb{R} \}. S≐{(−∞,x1​]×⋯×(−∞,xk​]:x1​,…,xk​∈R}.

for each H∈SH \in \mathcal{S}H∈S,

\begin{align} [X \in H] &= \{ \omega : X_1(\omega) \le x_1, \dots, X_k(\omega) \le x_k \} \\ &= \cap_{i \in [k]} \{ \omega : X_i(\omega) \le x_i \} \\ &= \cap_{i \in [k]} [X_i \le x_i]. \end{align}

  ⟸  :\impliedby:⟸: Suppose that each XiX_iXi​ is measurable, then [Xi≤xi]∈F,i∈[k][X_i \le x_i] \in \mathcal{F}, i \in [k][Xi​≤xi​]∈F,i∈[k].
It follows that [X∈H]∈F[X \in H] \in \mathcal{F}[X∈H]∈F, and S⊆L\mathcal{S} \subseteq \mathcal{L}S⊆L.
Since S\mathcal{S}S generates Rk\mathcal{R}^kRk, we have L=Rk\mathcal{L} = \mathcal{R}^kL=Rk.

  ⟹  :\implies:⟹: Suppose that XXX is measurable.
Fix an i∈[k]i \in [k]i∈[k].
By setting xj=∞x_j = \inftyxj​=∞ for each j≠ij \neq ij=i we have

[X∈H]=[Xi≤xi]∈F. [X \in H] = [X_i \le x_i] \in \mathcal{F}. [X∈H]=[Xi​≤xi​]∈F.

It concludes that XiX_iXi​ is measurable.

□\square□

Theorem. The σ\sigmaσ-field σ(X)=σ(X1,…,Xk)\sigma(X) = \sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_k)σ(X)=σ(X1​,…,Xk​) consists exactly of the sets [X∈H][X \in H][X∈H] for H∈RkH \in \mathcal{R}^kH∈Rk.

Proof.
Let G≐{[X∈H]:H∈Rk}⊆F\mathcal{G} \doteq \{ [X \in H] : H \in \mathcal{R}^k \} \subseteq \mathcal{F}G≐{[X∈H]:H∈Rk}⊆F.
Then G\mathcal{G}G is closed under complement and countable union:

\begin{align} \Omega - [X \in H] &= [ X \in (\mathbb{R}^k - H) ] \\ \cup_{n \ge 1} [ X \in H_n ] &= [X \in \cup_{n \ge 1} H_n]. \end{align}

Hence G\mathcal{G}G is a σ\sigmaσ-field, and σ(X)⊆G\sigma(X) \subseteq \mathcal{G}σ(X)⊆G.
But by the definition of σ(X)\sigma(X)σ(X) and G\mathcal{G}G, we also have G⊆σ(X)\mathcal{G} \subseteq \sigma(X)G⊆σ(X).

□\square□

Theorem. In order that a random variable YYY be measurable σ(X1,…,Xk)\sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_k)σ(X1​,…,Xk​), it is necessary and sufficient that there exists a measurable map f:Rk→Rf: \mathbb{R}^k \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:Rk→R s.t., Y(ω)=f(X1(ω),…,Xk(ω))Y(\omega) = f(X_1(\omega), \ldots, X_k(\omega))Y(ω)=f(X1​(ω),…,Xk​(ω)) for all ω\omegaω.

Proof.

  ⟸  :\impliedby:⟸: this direction is obvious.

  ⟹  :\implies:⟹: first, assume that YYY is a simple random variable which assumes value y1,…,yny_1, \ldots, y_ny1​,…,yn​.
Then the F\mathcal{F}F-sets [Y=yi],i∈[n][Y = y_i], i \in [n][Y=yi​],i∈[n] constitute a partition of Ω\OmegaΩ.
Via the previous theorem, there exists H1,…,Hn∈RkH_1, \ldots, H_n \in \mathcal{R}^kH1​,…,Hn​∈Rk, such that [Y=yi]=[X∈Hi][Y = y_i] = [X \in H_i][Y=yi​]=[X∈Hi​].

Note that the HiH_iHi​ are not necessarily disjoint.
But we have the following observation: fix an [Y=yi][Y = y_i][Y=yi​].
Then

\begin{align*} X( \{ \omega \in \Omega: Y(\omega) = y_i \} ) &\subseteq H_i, \\ X( \{ \omega \in \Omega: Y(\omega) = y_i \} ) \cap H_j &= \emptyset, \forall j \neq i. \end{align*}

The second observation is true, as otherwise, X−1(Hj)=[Y=yj]X^{-1}(H_j) = [Y = y_j]X−1(Hj​)=[Y=yj​] has non-empty intersection with [Y=yi][Y = y_i][Y=yi​], a contradiction.
At this point, we can set

Hˉi=Hi−∪j∈[n],j≠iHj, \bar H_i = H_i - \cup_{j \in [n], j \neq i} H_j, Hˉi​=Hi​−∪j∈[n],j=i​Hj​,

and set Hˉn+1=Rk−∪i∈[n]Hˉi\bar H_{n + 1} = \mathcal{R}^k - \cup_{i \in [n]} \bar H_iHˉn+1​=Rk−∪i∈[n]​Hˉi​.
Then it still holds that [X∈Hˉi]=[Y=yi],∀i∈[n][X \in \bar H_i] = [Y = y_i], \forall i \in [n][X∈Hˉi​]=[Y=yi​],∀i∈[n].
Define the function f:Rk→Rf: \mathbb{R}^k \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:Rk→R by

f=∑i∈[n]yi⋅IHˉi+0⋅IHˉn+1. f = \sum_{i \in [n]} y_i \cdot \mathbb{I}_{\bar H_i} + 0 \cdot \mathbb{I}_{\bar H_{n + 1}}. f=i∈[n]∑​yi​⋅IHˉi​​+0⋅IHˉn+1​​.

Clearly it holds that Y=f∘XY = f \circ XY=f∘X.

Next, we treat the general case.
There exists a sequence of simple random variables Yn→YY_n \rightarrow YYn​→Y.
Let fnf_nfn​ be the corresponding simple functions for which Yn=fn∘XY_n = f_n \circ XYn​=fn​∘X.
Since the fnf_nfn​ are measurable, so are the functions sup⁡nfn\sup_n f_nsupn​fn​ and inf⁡nfn\inf_n f_ninfn​fn​.
It follows that the set C≐{t∈Rk:sup⁡nfn(t)=inf⁡nfn(t)}C \doteq \{ t \in \mathbb{R}^k : \sup_n f_n(t) = \inf_n f_n(t) \}C≐{t∈Rk:supn​fn​(t)=infn​fn​(t)} for which the fnf_nfn​ converges lies in Rk\mathcal{R}^kRk.
Define the function fff by

f(t)={lim⁡nfn(t), if t∈C,0 if t∈Rk−C. f(t) = \begin{cases} \lim_n f_n(t), & \text{ if } t \in C, \\ 0 & \text{ if } t \in \mathbb{R}^k - C. \end{cases} f(t)={limn​fn​(t),0​ if t∈C, if t∈Rk−C.​

It is easy to check that fff is measurable.
For each ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω, we must have Y(ω)=lim⁡nYn(ω)=lim⁡nfn(X(ω))Y(\omega) = \lim_n Y_n (\omega) = \lim_n f_n(X(\omega))Y(ω)=limn​Yn​(ω)=limn​fn​(X(ω)); hence X(ω)∈CX(\omega) \in CX(ω)∈C, and lim⁡nfn(X(ω))=f(X(ω))\lim_n f_n(X(\omega)) = f(X(\omega))limn​fn​(X(ω))=f(X(ω)).
Then it holds that Y=f∘XY = f \circ XY=f∘X.

□\square□

Remark. We don’t know whether X([Y=yi])∈RkX([Y = y_i]) \in \mathcal{R}^kX([Y=yi​])∈Rk or not.
Otherwise, we can set Hˉi=X([Y=yi])\bar H_i = X([Y = y_i])Hˉi​=X([Y=yi​]) so that X−1(Hˉi)=[Y=yi]X^{-1}(\bar H_i) = [Y = y_i]X−1(Hˉi​)=[Y=yi​] and the Hˉi,i∈[n]\bar H_i, i \in [n]Hˉi​,i∈[n] are disjoint automatically.

Independence

Definition. A finite or countably infinite sequence X1,X2,…X_1, X_2, \ldotsX1​,X2​,… of random variables are independent, if σ(X1),σ(X2),…\sigma(X_1), \sigma(X_2), \ldotsσ(X1​),σ(X2​),… are independent.

Theorem. The random variables X1,…,XnX_1, \dots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ are independent if and only if for all xi∈R,i∈[n]x_i \in \mathbb{R}, i \in [n]xi​∈R,i∈[n],

Pr⁡[X1≤x1,…,Xn≤xn]=Pr⁡[X1≤x1]⋯Pr⁡[Xn≤xn]. \Pr[ X_1 \le x_1, \ldots, X_n \le x_n ] = \Pr[ X_1 \le x_1 ] \cdots \Pr[ X_n \le x_n ]. Pr[X1​≤x1​,…,Xn​≤xn​]=Pr[X1​≤x1​]⋯Pr[Xn​≤xn​].

Proof.
Since the σ\sigmaσ-field σ(Xi)\sigma(X_i)σ(Xi​) consists exactly of the sets [Xi∈H][X_i \in H][Xi​∈H] for H∈RH \in \mathcal{R}H∈R, X1,…,XnX_1, \dots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ are independent if and only if for all Hi∈R,i∈[n]H_i \in \mathcal{R}, i \in [n]Hi​∈R,i∈[n],

Pr⁡[X1∈H1,…,Xn∈Hn]=Pr⁡[X1∈H1]⋯Pr⁡[Xn∈Hn]. \Pr[ X_1 \in H_1, \ldots, X_n \in H_n ] = \Pr[ X_1 \in H_1 ] \cdots \Pr[ X_n \in H_n ]. Pr[X1​∈H1​,…,Xn​∈Hn​]=Pr[X1​∈H1​]⋯Pr[Xn​∈Hn​].

Since the intervals (−∞,xi](-\infty, x_i](−∞,xi​] forms a π\piπ-system generating R\mathcal{R}R, [Xi≤xi][X_i \le x_i][Xi​≤xi​] forms a π\piπ-system generating σ(Xi)\sigma(X_i)σ(Xi​), which proves the theorem.

□\square□

Corollary. If the XiX_iXi​ are simple random variables, then they are independent if and only if for all xi∈R,i∈[n]x_i \in \mathbb{R}, i \in [n]xi​∈R,i∈[n],

Pr⁡[X1=x1,…,Xn=xn]=Pr⁡[X1=x1]⋯Pr⁡[Xn=xn]. \Pr[ X_1 = x_1, \ldots, X_n = x_n ] = \Pr[ X_1 = x_1 ] \cdots \Pr[ X_n = x_n ]. Pr[X1​=x1​,…,Xn​=xn​]=Pr[X1​=x1​]⋯Pr[Xn​=xn​].

Let X=(X1,…,Xk)X = (X_1, \ldots, X_k)X=(X1​,…,Xk​) have distribution μ\muμ and distribution function FFF.
Let fi:Rk→Rf_i : \mathbb{R}^k \rightarrow \mathbb{R}fi​:Rk→R be the projection defined by fi(x1,…,xk)=xif_i(x_1,\ldots, x_k) = x_ifi​(x1​,…,xk​)=xi​, i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n].
It is measurable, and therefore Xi=fi∘XX_i = f_i \circ XXi​=fi​∘X is measurable.
Let the XiX_iXi​ have distributions μi\mu_iμi​ and distribution functions FiF_iFi​ (the marginals).
Consider the product measurable μ1×⋯×μk\mu_1 \times \dots \times \mu_kμ1​×⋯×μk​.

Theorem. The following conditions are equivalent

  1. XiX_iXi​ are independent if and only if

  2. μ=μ1×⋯×μk. \mu = \mu_1 \times \dots \times \mu_k. μ=μ1​×⋯×μk​.

  3. F(x1,…,xk)=F(x1)⋯F(xk). F(x_1, \ldots, x_k) = F(x_1) \dotsb F(x_k). F(x1​,…,xk​)=F(x1​)⋯F(xk​).

Proof.

μ(H)=(μ1×⋯×μk)(H),∀H∈Rk⟺μ(H1×⋯×Hk)=μ1(H1)⋯μk(Hk),∀H1,…,Hk∈R. \begin{aligned} \mu (H) &= \left( \mu_1 \times \dots \times \mu_k \right) (H), &\forall H \in \mathcal{R}^k \\ \Longleftrightarrow \mu (H_1 \times \cdots \times H_k) &= \mu_1 (H_1) \cdots \mu_k (H_k), &\forall H_1, \ldots, H_k \in \mathcal{R}. \end{aligned} μ(H)⟺μ(H1​×⋯×Hk​)​=(μ1​×⋯×μk​)(H),=μ1​(H1​)⋯μk​(Hk​),​∀H∈Rk∀H1​,…,Hk​∈R.​

Therefore, conditions (1) and (2) are equivalent.

Since the intervals (−∞,xi](-\infty, x_i](−∞,xi​] forms a π\piπ-system generating R\mathcal{R}R, [Xi≤xi][X_i \le x_i][Xi​≤xi​] forms a π\piπ-system generating σ(Xi)\sigma(X_i)σ(Xi​), conditions (2) and (3) are equivalent.

□\square□

Theorem. Suppose that μi\mu_iμi​ has density fif_ifi​. If the XiX_iXi​ are independent, then μ\muμ has density

f(x)=f1(x1)⋯fk(xk). f(x) = f_1(x_1) \dotsb f_k(x_k). f(x)=f1​(x1​)⋯fk​(xk​).

Proof.
Since the density function are non-negative, via Fubini’s theorem, for each H1,…,Hk∈RH_1, \ldots, H_k \in \mathcal{R}H1​,…,Hk​∈R,

Pr⁡[X1∈H1]⋯Pr⁡[Xk∈Hk]=∫H1f1 dμ1⋯∫Hkfk dμk=∫H1×⋯×Hkf1⋯fk dμ=Pr⁡[X∈H1×⋯×Hk]. \begin{aligned} \Pr[X_1 \in H_1] \cdots \Pr[X_k \in H_k] &= \int_{H_1} f_1 \, d\mu_1 \cdots \int_{H_k} f_k \, d\mu_k \\ &= \int_{H_1 \times \dots \times H_k} f_1 \cdots f_k \, d\mu \\ &= \Pr[ X \in H_1 \times \dots \times H_k ]. \end{aligned} Pr[X1​∈H1​]⋯Pr[Xk​∈Hk​]​=∫H1​​f1​dμ1​⋯∫Hk​​fk​dμk​=∫H1​×⋯×Hk​​f1​⋯fk​dμ=Pr[X∈H1​×⋯×Hk​].​

It follows by π−λ\pi-\lambdaπ−λ theorem, for each H∈RkH \in \mathcal{R}^kH∈Rk, we have

∫Hf1⋯fk dμ=Pr⁡[X∈H]. \int_{H} f_1 \cdots f_k \, d\mu = \Pr[ X \in H ]. ∫H​f1​⋯fk​dμ=Pr[X∈H].

□\square□

Theorem. Let

X1,1,X1,2,…X2,1,X2,2,………… \begin{matrix} X_{1, 1}, &X_{1, 2}, &\ldots \\ X_{2, 1}, &X_{2, 2}, &\ldots \\ \ldots &\ldots &\ldots \end{matrix} X1,1​,X2,1​,…​X1,2​,X2,2​,…​………​

be a (possibly countably infinite) sequence of independent random variables.
The σ\sigmaσ-fields Fn≐σ(Xn,1,Xn,2,…)\mathcal{F}_n \doteq \sigma(X_{n, 1}, X_{n, 2}, \ldots )Fn​≐σ(Xn,1​,Xn,2​,…), n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+ are independent.

Proof.
For each n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+, define the class

An≐{Xn,i1−1(Hi1)∩…∩Xn,ik−1(Hik):1≤i1<i2<…<ikHi1,…,Hik∈R}, \mathcal{A}_n \doteq \left\{ X_{n, i_1}^{-1} (H_{i_1}) \cap \ldots \cap X_{n, i_k}^{-1} (H_{i_k}) : \begin{matrix} 1 \le i_1 < i_2 < \ldots < i_k \\ H_{i_1}, \ldots, H_{i_k} \in \mathcal{R} \end{matrix} \right\}, An​≐{Xn,i1​−1​(Hi1​​)∩…∩Xn,ik​−1​(Hik​​):1≤i1​<i2​<…<ik​Hi1​​,…,Hik​​∈R​},

which is the finite intersections of the sets Xn,k−1(H),k∈N+,H∈RX_{n, k}^{-1} (H), k \in \mathbb{N}^+, H \in \mathcal{R}Xn,k−1​(H),k∈N+,H∈R.
It is easy to see that ∅∈An\emptyset \in \mathcal{A}_n∅∈An​, and An\mathcal{A}_nAn​ is a π\piπ-system.
Further,

  • An\mathcal{A}_nAn​ generates Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​, i.e., σ(An)=Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) = \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)=Fn​:

    • σ(An)⊆Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) \subseteq \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)⊆Fn​: via definition of Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​, Xn,k−1(H)∈FnX_{n, k}^{-1} (H) \in \mathcal{F}_nXn,k−1​(H)∈Fn​, for each k∈N+,H∈Rk \in \mathbb{N}^+, H \in \mathcal{R}k∈N+,H∈R.
      Hence, each element in An\mathcal{A}_nAn​ belongs to Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​, and σ(An)⊆Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) \subseteq \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)⊆Fn​.

    • σ(An)⊇Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) \supseteq \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)⊇Fn​: via definition of An\mathcal{A}_nAn​, Xn,k−1(H)∈AnX_{n, k}^{-1} (H) \in \mathcal{A}_nXn,k−1​(H)∈An​, for each k∈N+,H∈Rk \in \mathbb{N}^+, H \in \mathcal{R}k∈N+,H∈R.
      Hence, each Xn,kX_{n, k}Xn,k​ is measurable σ(An)\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n)σ(An​).
      Via definition of Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​, σ(An)⊇Fn\sigma(\mathcal{A}_n) \supseteq \mathcal{F}_nσ(An​)⊇Fn​.

  • The An\mathcal{A}_nAn​ are independent: let n1,…,nmn_1, \ldots, n_mn1​,…,nm​ be a finite sequence of indexes in N+\mathbb{N}^+N+.
    Suppose that for each j∈[m]j \in [m]j∈[m],

    Bnj≐Xnj,i1(j)−1(Hi1(j))∩…∩Xnj,ik(j)−1(Hik(j)). B_{n_j} \doteq X_{n_j, i_1(j)}^{-1} (H_{i_1(j)}) \cap \ldots \cap X_{n_j, i_k(j)}^{-1} (H_{i_{k}(j)}). Bnj​​≐Xnj​,i1​(j)−1​(Hi1​(j)​)∩…∩Xnj​,ik​(j)−1​(Hik​(j)​).

    Then

    Pr⁡[Bn1∩…∩Bnm]=Pr⁡[∩j∈[m](Xnj,i1(j)−1(Hi1(j))∩…∩Xnj,ik(j)−1(Hik(j)))]=∏j∈[m]Pr⁡[Xnj,i1(j)∈Hi1(j)]⋯Pr⁡[Xnj,ik(j)∈Hik(j)]=∏j∈[m]Pr⁡[Bnj]. \begin{aligned} \Pr[ B_{n_1} \cap \ldots \cap B_{n_m} ] &= \Pr\left[ \cap_{j \in [m]} \left( X_{n_j, i_1(j)}^{-1} (H_{i_1(j)}) \cap \ldots \cap X_{n_j, i_k(j)}^{-1} (H_{i_{k}(j)}) \right) \right] \\ &= \prod_{j \in [m]} \Pr[ X_{n_j, i_1(j)} \in H_{i_1(j)}] \cdots \Pr[X_{n_j, i_k(j)} \in H_{i_{k}(j)} ] \\ &= \prod_{j \in [m]} \Pr[B_{n_j}]. \end{aligned} Pr[Bn1​​∩…∩Bnm​​]​=Pr[∩j∈[m]​(Xnj​,i1​(j)−1​(Hi1​(j)​)∩…∩Xnj​,ik​(j)−1​(Hik​(j)​))]=j∈[m]∏​Pr[Xnj​,i1​(j)​∈Hi1​(j)​]⋯Pr[Xnj​,ik​(j)​∈Hik​(j)​]=j∈[m]∏​Pr[Bnj​​].​

It follows that the Fn\mathcal{F}_nFn​ are independent.

□\square□

Expectation

Theorem. If XXX ane YYY are independent and integrable, then

E[XY]=E[X]E[Y]. \mathbb{E}[ X Y ] = \mathbb{E}[ X ] \mathbb{E}[ Y ]. E[XY]=E[X]E[Y].

Proof.
The claim holds trivially if XXX and YYY are simple random variables.

We treat the general case.
There exists simple random variables XnX_nXn​ and YnY_nYn​ such that

  1. Xn→X,∣Xn∣↑∣X∣X_n \rightarrow X, |X_n| \uparrow |X|Xn​→X,∣Xn​∣↑∣X∣ and Yn→Y,∣Yn∣↑∣Y∣Y_n \rightarrow Y, |Y_n| \uparrow |Y|Yn​→Y,∣Yn​∣↑∣Y∣;

  2. The XnX_nXn​ are measurable σ(X)\sigma(X)σ(X) and the YnY_nYn​ are measurable σ(Y)\sigma(Y)σ(Y).

It follows that the XnX_nXn​ and YnY_nYn​ are independent for each n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+.
Now E[∣Xn∣⋅∣Yn∣]=E[∣Xn∣]E[∣Yn∣]\mathbb{E}[ |X_n| \cdot |Y_n| ] = \mathbb{E}[ |X_n| ] \mathbb{E}[ |Y_n| ]E[∣Xn​∣⋅∣Yn​∣]=E[∣Xn​∣]E[∣Yn​∣].
Via monotone convergence theorem,

E[∣X∣⋅∣Y∣]=lim⁡nE[∣Xn∣⋅∣Yn∣]=lim⁡nE[∣Xn∣]E[∣Yn∣]=E[∣X∣]E[∣Y∣]≤∞. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[ |X| \cdot |Y| ] &= \lim_n \mathbb{E}[ |X_n| \cdot |Y_n| ] \\ &= \lim_n \mathbb{E}[ |X_n| ] \mathbb{E}[ |Y_n| ] \\ &= \mathbb{E}[ |X| ] \mathbb{E}[ |Y| ] \\ &\le \infty. \end{aligned} E[∣X∣⋅∣Y∣]​=nlim​E[∣Xn​∣⋅∣Yn​∣]=nlim​E[∣Xn​∣]E[∣Yn​∣]=E[∣X∣]E[∣Y∣]≤∞.​

Therefore, E[∣XY∣]=E[∣X∣⋅∣Y∣]\mathbb{E}[ |XY| ] = \mathbb{E}[ |X| \cdot |Y| ]E[∣XY∣]=E[∣X∣⋅∣Y∣] is integrable.
Via monotone convergence theorem again, we have

lim⁡nE[inf⁡k≥n(2∣XY∣−∣XkYk−XY∣)]=E[lim⁡ninf⁡k≥n(2∣XY∣−∣XkYk−XY∣)]. \begin{aligned} \lim_n \mathbb{E} \left[ \inf_{k \ge n} \left( 2 |X Y| - |X_k Y_k - X Y| \right)\right] &= \mathbb{E} \left[ \lim_n \inf_{k \ge n} \left( 2 |X Y| - |X_k Y_k - X Y| \right)\right]. \end{aligned} nlim​E[k≥ninf​(2∣XY∣−∣Xk​Yk​−XY∣)]​=E[nlim​k≥ninf​(2∣XY∣−∣Xk​Yk​−XY∣)].​

Therefore,

2E[∣XY∣]−lim⁡nE[sup⁡k≥n∣XkYk−XY∣]=2E[∣XY∣]−E[lim⁡ninf⁡k≥n∣XkYk−XY∣] 2 \mathbb{E}[ |X Y| ] - \lim_n \mathbb{E} \left[ \sup_{k \ge n} |X_k Y_k - X Y| \right] = 2 \mathbb{E}[ |X Y| ] - \mathbb{E} \left[ \lim_n \inf_{k \ge n} |X_k Y_k - X Y| \right] 2E[∣XY∣]−nlim​E[k≥nsup​∣Xk​Yk​−XY∣]=2E[∣XY∣]−E[nlim​k≥ninf​∣Xk​Yk​−XY∣]

Noting that ∣XY∣|XY|∣XY∣ is integrable and that XkYk→XYX_k Y_k \rightarrow X YXk​Yk​→XY, we have

lim⁡nE[sup⁡k≥n∣XkYk−XY∣]=0, \lim_n \mathbb{E} \left[ \sup_{k \ge n} |X_k Y_k - X Y| \right] = 0, nlim​E[k≥nsup​∣Xk​Yk​−XY∣]=0,

and

lim⁡n∣E[XnYn]−E[XY]∣≤lim⁡nE[∣XnYn−XY∣]≤lim⁡nE[sup⁡k≥n∣XkYk−XY∣]=0, \begin{aligned} \lim_n |\mathbb{E}[ X_n Y_n] - \mathbb{E}[X Y]| &\le \lim_n \mathbb{E} \left[ |X_n Y_n - X Y| \right] \\ &\le \lim_n \mathbb{E} \left[ \sup_{k \ge n} |X_k Y_k - X Y| \right] \\ &= 0, \end{aligned} nlim​∣E[Xn​Yn​]−E[XY]∣​≤nlim​E[∣Xn​Yn​−XY∣]≤nlim​E[k≥nsup​∣Xk​Yk​−XY∣]=0,​

which proves that E[XY]=E[XnYn]=E[Xn]E[Yn]\mathbb{E}[X Y] = \mathbb{E}[ X_n Y_n] = \mathbb{E}[X_n] \mathbb{E}[ Y_n ]E[XY]=E[Xn​Yn​]=E[Xn​]E[Yn​].

□\square□

Reference

[1] P. Billingsley, Probability and measure, 3rd ed. New York: Wiley, 1995.
